    <summary>Articles in this issue: How KPop Demon Hunters Star EJAE Topped the Charts Ed Zitron Gets Paid to Love AI. Now She Wants to Do It in Congress I Thought I Knew Silicon Valley. I Was Wrong Elon Musk Is Out to Rule Space. Can Anyone Stop Him? One Vigilante, 22 Cell Tower Fires, and a World of Conspiracies The Superyacht, the Billionaire, and a Wildly Improbable Disaster at Sea The Baby Died. Whose Fault Is It? What It’s Like Watching Dozens of Bodies Decompose (for Science) Why Did a $10 Billion Startup Let Me Vibe-Code for Them—and Why Did I Love It? AI Isn’t Coming for Hollywood. It's Already Arrived Lisa Su Runs AMD—and Is Out for Nvidia’s Blood Psychedelic Therapy Crashed and Burned. MAHA Might Bring It Back Life Without Screens: This Camp Is a Teen’s Worst Nightmare A Head-to-Toe Breakdown of Social Media’s Billion-Dollar Remedies Bryan Johnson Is Going to Die The Next Thing You Smell Could Ruin Your Life Who Controls Your Health? Test Your Knowledge of the MAHA Movement How Trump Killed Cancer Research Animals Are the Original Wellness Influencers Does Anyone Know What ‘Wellness’ Means Anymore? Where Are All the AI Drugs? The Enshittification of American Power Cloning Came to Polo. Then Things Got Truly Uncivilized I Let AI Agents Plan My Vacation—and It Wasn't Terrible My Couples Retreat With 3 AI Chatbots and the Humans Who Love Them How to Beat Jet Lag The Definitive, Insane, Swimsuit-Bursting Story of the Steroid Olympics How Steve Jobs Wrote the Greatest Commencement Speech Ever The Blind Leading the Gamers Demis Hassabis Embraces the Future of Work in the Age of AI Shop Like a Supervillian Esoteric Programming Languages Are Fun—Until They Kill the Joke The Epic Rise and Fall of a Dark-Web Psychedelics Kingpin 3 Teens Almost Got Away With Murder. Then Police Found Their Google Searches ‘A Billion Streams and No Fans’: Inside a $10 Million AI Music Fraud Case What to Expect When You’re Convicted Who Even Is a Criminal Now? How to Win Followers and Scamfluence People For Tech Whistleblowers, There’s Safety in Numbers Bluesky Is Plotting a Total Takeover of the Social Internet Airbnb Is in Midlife Crisis Mode North Korea Stole Your Job If Anthropic Succeeds, a Nation of Benevolent AI Geniuses Could Be Born Inside arXiv—the Most Transformative Platform in All of Science The Worm That No Computer Scientist Can Crack The Best Programming Language for the End of the World Angelina Jolie Was Right About Computers How Software Engineers Actually Use AI Wired is a full-color monthly American magazine, published in both print and online editions, that reports on how emerging technologies affect culture, the economy and politics. Monthly edition, best run at the start of every month.</summary>

    <summary>Articles in this issue: Trust and science: the essential elements missing from plastics treaty talks From MRI to Ozempic: breakthroughs that show why fundamental research must be protected We need a new Turing test to assess AI’s real-world knowledge What now for the global plastics treaty? ‘Gland-in-a-dish’ secretes stress hormone like the real thing Sugarcane genomes offer sweet surprise: mystery ancestor Stinkbug ‘ear’ actually hosts parasite-fighting fungi How to grow crystals when and where you want them Blood tests are now approved for Alzheimer’s: how accurate are they? What’s the cap on human energy expenditure? Elite athletes reveal ‘metabolic ceiling’ Surprise meteorite debris uncovered on Moon’s far side How scientists are pushing back against Trump’s funding ‘deal’ for universities People with blindness can read again after retinal implant Is academic research becoming too competitive? Nature examines the data The world’s first plastics treaty is in crisis: can it be salvaged? 7 basic science discoveries that changed the world Plants have a secret language that scientists are only now starting to decipher AI can supercharge inequality — unless the public learns to control it How do you know what I know you know? Steven Pinker on common knowledge John Gurdon obituary: Biologist who made cloning possible Environmental treaties are paralysed — here’s how we can do better How to understand exoplanets — space scientists call on lab-based chemists to help Universities can harness AI to make learning intuitive Don’t overlook the plastic footprint of fireworks Treat children as citizen co-researchers in health technology Ethics must keep pace with embryo research Cake to the rescue: how these PhD students are cooking up a sense of community Preserving Pompeii’s past, one step at a time Ultrasound-driven artificial muscles can grasp, flex and swim Distorted representations of age and gender are reflected in AI models Early- and late-diagnosed autism are genetically distinct To make water, exoplanets might just need some pressure Wired for growth: neuron–tumour signalling in the lung and brain increases growth of a hard-to-treat cancer Building wet planets through high-pressure magma–hydrogen reactions Continuous operation of a coherent 3,000-qubit system A full-featured 2D flash chip enabled by system integration Video‐rate tunable colour electronic paper with human resolution Ultrasound-driven programmable artificial muscles Decoding the redox behaviour of copper in Ullmann-type coupling reactions A circular economy approach for the global lithium-ion battery supply chain Magnetotelluric evidence for a melt-rich magmatic reservoir beneath Mayotte Age and gender distortion in online media and large language models A domed pachycephalosaur from the early Cretaceous of Mongolia Polygenic and developmental profiles of autism differ by age at diagnosis Transitions in dynamical regime and neural mode during perceptual decisions A neuronal architecture underlying autonomic dysreflexia PICALM Alzheimer’s risk allele causes aberrant lipid droplets in microglia Energy deficiency selects crowded live epithelial cells for extrusion Programmable antisense oligomers for phage functional genomics Monoclonal antibodies protect against pandrug-resistant Klebsiella pneumoniae Myeloid progenitor dysregulation fuels immunosuppressive macrophages in tumours Peroxisomal metabolism of branched fatty acids regulates energy homeostasis Neuronal activity-dependent mechanisms of small cell lung cancer pathogenesis Functional synapses between neurons and small cell lung cancer Engineered prime editors with minimal genomic errors Spatial joint profiling of DNA methylome and transcriptome in tissues Structure and mechanism of the mitochondrial calcium transporter NCLX Carbon implications of wood harvesting and forest management Reply to: Carbon implications of wood harvesting and forest management On anisotropy in cubic Cu2O photoelectrodes Reply to: On anisotropy in cubic Cu2O photoelectrodes Author Correction: Crystal structure of heliorhodopsin Author Correction: Prophylactic TNF blockade uncouples efficacy and toxicity in dual CTLA-4 and PD-1 immunotherapy Author Correction: Ribonucleotide incorporation into mitochondrial DNA drives inflammation Author Correction: EBI2 augments Tfh cell fate by promoting interaction with IL-2-quenching dendritic cells Publisher Correction: Psilocybin’s lasting action requires pyramidal cell types and 5-HT2A receptors Robotics Nature is a weekly international multidisciplinary scientific journal publishing peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nauture also provides rapid, authoritative, insightful and arresting news and interpretation of topical and coming trends affecting science, scientists and the wider public.</summary>
